abstract.text: A protocol that defines the requirements for a video decoder.

inlineContent.text: This protocol provides an interface for
to create and interact with MediaExtension video decoders.
objects are always instantiated by Video Toolbox.
Developers who wish to build MediaExtension video decoders using this API need to include a
, provisioning profile, and specialized dictionary in their Info.plist file when building their extensions.
For more information, see
, and
Once a user installs and runs the host app, embedded video decoder extensions become available to any app on the user’s system that opts in to using them by calling
objects run in a sandboxed process without access to the filesystem, network, and other kernel resources.
The following sections explain the video decoder life cycle and performing decoding operations.
The first time Video Toolbox opens a decoder in a process, it creates an instance of the
factory object. It then calls its
method for each decoder instance it needs. A decoder can evaluate the
and
that the system provides and confirm whether it can decode the specified format. If the decoder can’t decode the format, the factory routine needs to return the error
. This sequence of events happens within
Once instantiated, a decoder can call back to the provided
object to notify Video Toolbox of its output
requirements. It can make these calls multiple times if output requirements change in response to properties receiving new values or due to observed bitstream characteristics.
Properties can receive queries or new values on the decoder at any time, before, during or after frame decode, unless otherwise noted. These calls generally correspond to
and
calls on the
which opened the decoder. There may be cases where Video Toolbox directly sets or queries properties as well.
The framework serializes calls to
and doesn’t send a new frame to the decoder until the last
returns, unless decoding happens asynchronously. These calls correspond to
calls on the owning
Video decoders need to write their output frames into
objects allocated by the
object’s
method. Obtaining pixel buffers from any other source may degrade performance or result in other issues.
If the decoder’s internal decoding queue is full and it can’t decode more frames, its
property value returns
. It returns
once the decoder can start accepting new frames again. This generally occurs after an earlier asynchronous frame completes.
If a change occurs in the format description on incoming
objects,
calls
to confirm whether the decoder can transition to the new format description. If that method response is
, the system usually closes the decoder and creates a new instance for the changed format description. A call to
can trigger a call of
, or Video Toolbox calls this method if it sees a format description change on incoming
objects.

abstract.text: A reference to a buffer of media data.
A video codec type.
A type you use to interact with video format descriptions.
An image buffer that holds pixels in main memory.
Work directly with hardware-accelerated video encoding and decoding capabilities.
A reference to a decompression session.
Indicates whether the session can decode frames with the given format description.
Creates a session for decompressing video frames.
Decompresses a video frame and invokes the output callback when the decompression completes.
Loads decoders appropriate for the client’s professional video workflows.
Retrieves a property on a Video Toolbox session.
Sets a property on a VideoToolbox session.
A false value.
A true value.
This framework provides a means for developers to create format readers, video decoders, and RAW processors for media that the system doesn’t natively support.
An object that guides the video decoder operation on a per-frame basis.
A type that represents a non-error status related to a frame decode operation.
An error code that indicates the extension doesn’t support an aspect of the media.
A protocol that defines the requirements for a video decoder.
The actual number of threads the decoder uses.
Asks the extension whether the decoder can decode frames with the format description that you specify.
A Boolean that specifies whether the content has interframe dependencies, if the decoder knows.
Requests the extension to decode a video frame.
A Boolean value that indicates the readiness of the decoder to accept more sample buffers.
Provides a list of output pixel formats where the decoder supports reduced resolution decoding.
Indicates whether the decoder produces RAW output which requires the use of a RAW processor.
The recommended number of threads for the decoder to use.
A request to decode at a lower resolution than full-size.
Provides hints about quality tradeoffs between pixel formats.
A protocol that defines a factory to create new video decoders for a codec type that the extension implements.
Creates a new video decoder that matches the codec type, format description, decoder specifications, and pixel buffer manager that you specify.
Describes pixel buffer requirements and creates new pixel buffers.
Generates a pixel buffer using the session’s pixel buffer pool.
A notification that indicates a change to the decoder’s readiness to process additional media data.
Include an entitlement to indicate your extension is a MediaExtension video decoder.
Include a property list dictionary to describe a video decoder.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
